page.title: 12Butlin's Holiday Camp
page.content: In 1936 William Butlin,who came from Canada,built the camp which the family kept until 1977 when it was bought by the Rank Organisation.At the outbreak of war,in 1939,the Admiralty took it over as a training establishment and named it H.M.S.Royal Arthur.On the German radio they twice claimed they had sunk it! In 1946 it was re-opened to 4,000 holiday makers on full board. During the Fifties and Sixties the number catered for increased to 12,000 but as the accommodation has been up- graded with private baths and toilets, the maximum is now 8,000.In 1967 self- catering chalets were first built and 1985 saw the first sites established for tourers at Â£8 per night.The camp was flooded in 1953 and fire destroyed a section in 1972.For today's visitor Butlin's provides every possible entertainment and amenity.
